chapter.title: Creating &kiwi; Images
chapter.para: &kiwi; is a tool to create operating system images that can be easily copied to new physical or virtual machines. This chapter will present information on creating &s4sa; images with &kiwi;.

sect1.title: Cleaning Up an Instance Before Using It as a Master Image
sect1.para: Using a system like &kiwi;, it is possible to use an image of an already-configured master instance on multiple systems. However, normally such an image would contain certain configuration data that should not be copied along with the rest of the system.
To avoid needing to clean up manually, use the script clone-master-clean-up (available from the package of the same name). It deletes the following data automatically:

listitem.para: SUSE registration information and repositories from SUSE
Shell history, mails, cron jobs, temporary files, log files, random seeds
The generated HANA-Firewall script (but not the configuration itself)

sect1.para: Additionally, sudo settings are reset and you can choose to set up a new &rootuser; password. This script also ensures that, if the first-boot section of the installation workflow was used for the original installation, it is run again on the next boot.

sect1.title: Creating Images with &kiwi;
sect1.para: &sles4sap; now supports creating images with &kiwi; using the template from the package kiwi-template-sap. However, there are certain restrictions in the current implementation:

listitem.para: Only building VMX disk images is supported. Building other image types is not supported.
You must provide an ISO image of &sles4sap; at /tmp/SLES4SAP.iso, as the &obs; does not contain all necessary packages.
